DOC.HEAD: Life Terms for Three Palestinians in Fire Bomb Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A military court sentenced three Palestinians to life prison terms Wednesday for a firebomb attack on an Israeli bus that killed a rabbi's daughter, her three children and an Israeli soldier, the army said. After sentencing, Israeli soldiers tried to assault the prisoners and turned on journalists as they left the court, Israel radio reported. No injuries were reported. Last week, the court in Ramallah found Ahmad Takruri, 22; Jumaa Adam, 20, and Mahmud Abu Harbish, 19, guilty of causing the deaths by throwing firebombs at the bus as it passed through the biblical town of Jericho in the occupied West Bank. It found the attack to be premeditated, and also convicted the men of preparing firebombs in three prior instances. Adam was given two years beyond life because of a two-year suspended sentence for an earlier conviction. The attack occurred on Oct. 30, 1988, two days before national elections. It was thought to have given a last-minute boost to rightist parties such as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud bloc, which urged tougher action against the Palestinian uprising. There had been expectations the three would be sentenced to death after military Judge Lt. Col. Yosef Shapira said last week the court was not bound by the prosecution's request for life sentences. The army prosecutor, Capt. Moshe Bachar, said at the time a request for the death sentence was rejected in consultations with high-ranking authorities. The only person ever executed in Israel was Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann, who was hanged in 1962. Chief of Staff Dan Shomron said at the time of the attack that it was ``spontaneous'' and ill-planned. ``It was a group of guys who were sitting around at night playing cards and decided to throw a firebomb at a passing bus,'' he said. The three were said to have hidden in a banana grove and hurled firebombs through the open windows of the passenger bus traveling from Tiberias to Jerusalem. Rachel Weiss, a 27-year-old school teacher, and her sons Netanel, 3, Rafael, 2, and 9-month-old Efraim were burned to death. David Delarosa, a soldier who tried to rescue the family, suffered severe burns and died later. On Oct. 30, a Jerusalem court handed down the stiffest sentence of the 2-year-old uprising against Israeli rule, giving a Palestinian 16 life terms for forcing a passenger bus off a cliff and killing 16 people. At least 631 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis during the revolt, and 43 Israelis have been slain. Another 161 Palestinians have been killed by their fellow Arabs as suspected collaborators with Israel.
